message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is young and has no personal or family history of serious illnesses. The mass is mobile, nontender, and has regular borders, which are suggestive of fibroadenoma. Invasive ductal carcinoma and lobular carcinoma are unlikely since they usually occur in older patients, and the ultrasound suggests a benign mass. Medullary carcinoma is not typically associated with breast enlargement or contraceptive use.

Invasive ductal carcinoma and lobular carcinoma are both types of breast cancer, while medullary carcinoma is a rare type of breast cancer and typically presents as a firm, immobile mass. However, a biopsy would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Fibroadenoma is the most common benign breast tumor in young women and fits the description of the mass found in the patient. The ultrasound findings also support a diagnosis of fibroadenoma. Invasive ductal carcinoma would present differently on physical exam and ultrasound. Lobular and medullary carcinoma are less common than invasive ductal carcinoma and also present differently on exams and ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor that commonly occurs in women in their 20s and 30s, is usually painless and has a rubbery texture, mobile, and well-defined borders. Breast ultrasound shows a round and solid homogeneous mass with well-defined borders and low echogenicity, which is consistent with the characteristics of fibroadenoma. The other options are different types of breast cancer, which are less likely given the patient's age, the characteristics of the mass, and the absence of other symptoms.

Invasive ductal carcinoma, lobular carcinoma, and medullary carcinoma are all forms of breast cancer and are less likely in a young patient with a benign-looking mass on ultrasound.
